units.title: Suppress mesoderm-derived immune cells in organoid culture
units.text: the organoid culture method suppresses mesoderm-derived immune cell/microglia presence to achieve a more consistent forebrain identity and cell composition.
units.rationale: Describes a specific step to modify organoid composition.

units.title: Study astroglia- and neuron-dependent pathologies without immune interference
units.text: This allowed us to specifically address initial astroglia- and neuron-dependent pathologies without immune or secondary inflammatory responses.
units.rationale: Specifies the experimental condition for isolating neuronal and astrocytic effects.

units.title: Supplement ALI‑COs with microglia or allogeneic immune cells
units.text: supplementation of ALI-COs with microglia/allogeneic immune cells could address immune-related pathogenesis in ALS/FTD in the future.
units.rationale: Proposes a concrete addition to the organoid model to study immune contributions.

units.title: Slice organoids to create paired control‑treatment samples
units.text: The slicing of prematurity organoids provides an important advantage as two adjacent slices derived from the same organoid could serve as a control–treatment pair, increasing the confidence in analyzing drug-related effects.
units.rationale: Outlines a procedural advantage for experimental replication and comparison.

units.title: Use adjacent organoid slices as internal controls
units.text: Sliced organoids provide an important advantage as two adjacent slices derived from the same organoid could serve as a control–treatment pair, increasing the confidence in analyzing drug-related effects.
units.rationale: Emphasizes the practical step of generating internal controls from a single organoid.
